# Mickey Mouse

Mickey Mouse  
---

**Mickey Mouse** is a [funny animal](/wiki/Funny_animal "Funny animal")
[cartoon](/wiki/Animated_cartoon "Animated cartoon")
[character](/wiki/Fictional_character "Fictional character") and the
[mascot](/wiki/Mascot "Mascot") of [The Walt Disney
Company](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company"). He was
created by [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney") and [Ub
Iwerks](/wiki/Ub_Iwerks "Ub Iwerks") at the [Walt Disney
Studios](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios "Walt Disney Animation Studios")
in 1928. An [anthropomorphic](/wiki/Anthropomorphism "Anthropomorphism") mouse
who typically wears red shorts, large yellow shoes, and white gloves, Mickey
is one of the world's most recognizable characters.

Mickey first appeared in the short _[Plane Crazy](/wiki/Plane_Crazy "Plane
Crazy")_ , debuting publicly in the [short film](/wiki/Short_film "Short
film") _[Steamboat Willie](/wiki/Steamboat_Willie "Steamboat Willie")_ (1928),
one of the first [sound cartoons](/wiki/Sound_film "Sound film"). He went on
to appear in over 130 films, including _[The Band
Concert](/wiki/The_Band_Concert "The Band Concert")_ (1935), _[Brave Little
Tailor](/wiki/Brave_Little_Tailor "Brave Little Tailor")_ (1938), and
_[Fantasia](/wiki/Fantasia_\(1940_film\) "Fantasia \(1940 film\)")_ (1940).
Mickey appeared primarily in short films, but also occasionally in feature-
length films. Ten of Mickey's cartoons were nominated for the [Academy Award
for Best Animated Short Film](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Short_Film
"Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film"), one of which, _[Lend a
Paw](/wiki/Lend_a_Paw "Lend a Paw")_ , won the award in
[1942](/wiki/14th_Academy_Awards "14th Academy Awards"). In 1978, Mickey
became the first cartoon character to have a star on the [Hollywood Walk of
Fame](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame "Hollywood Walk of Fame").

Beginning in 1930, Mickey has also been featured extensively as a [comic
strip](/wiki/Comic_strip "Comic strip") character. His self-titled newspaper
strip, drawn primarily by [Floyd Gottfredson](/wiki/Floyd_Gottfredson "Floyd
Gottfredson"), ran for 45 years. Mickey has also appeared in comic books such
as [Disney Italy](/wiki/Disney_comics#Italy "Disney comics")'s
_[Topolino](/wiki/Topolino "Topolino")_ , _[MM Mickey Mouse Mystery
Magazine](/wiki/MM_Mickey_Mouse_Mystery_Magazine "MM Mickey Mouse Mystery
Magazine")_ , and _[Wizards of Mickey](/wiki/Wizards_of_Mickey "Wizards of
Mickey")_ , and in television series such as _[The Mickey Mouse
Club](/wiki/The_Mickey_Mouse_Club "The Mickey Mouse Club")_ (1955–1996) and
others. He also appears in other media such as video games as well as
merchandising and is a meetable character at the Disney parks.

Mickey generally appears alongside his girlfriend [Minnie
Mouse](/wiki/Minnie_Mouse "Minnie Mouse"), his pet dog
[Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(Disney\) "Pluto \(Disney\)"), his friends [Donald
Duck](/wiki/Donald_Duck "Donald Duck") and [Goofy](/wiki/Goofy "Goofy"), and
his nemesis [Pete](/wiki/Pete_\(Disney\) "Pete \(Disney\)"), among others (see
[Mickey Mouse universe](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_universe "Mickey Mouse universe")).
Though originally characterized as a mischievous [antihero](/wiki/Antihero
"Antihero"), Mickey was rebranded over time as an [everyman](/wiki/Everyman
"Everyman"), usually seen as a flawed, but adventurous hero. In 2009, Disney
began to rebrand the character again by putting less emphasis on his pleasant,
cheerful side and reintroducing the more mischievous and adventurous sides of
his personality, beginning with the video game _[Epic
Mickey](/wiki/Epic_Mickey "Epic Mickey")_.[3]

## Origin

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4e/Mickey_Mouse_concept_art.jpg/220px-
Mickey_Mouse_concept_art.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_concept_art.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_concept_art.jpg "Enlarge")

[Concept art](/wiki/Concept_art "Concept art") of Mickey from early 1928; the
sketches are the earliest known drawings of the character, from the collection
of [The Walt Disney Family Museum](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Family_Museum "The
Walt Disney Family Museum").

> "I only hope that we never lose sight of one thing – that it was all started
> by a mouse."
>
> — Walt Disney, _[Disneyland](/wiki/Walt_Disney_anthology_television_series
> "Walt Disney anthology television series")_ ; October 27, 1954

Mickey Mouse was created as a replacement for [Oswald the Lucky
Rabbit](/wiki/Oswald_the_Lucky_Rabbit "Oswald the Lucky Rabbit"), an earlier
cartoon character created by the Disney studio for [Charles
Mintz](/wiki/Charles_Mintz "Charles Mintz"), a film producer who distributed
product through [Universal Studios](/wiki/Universal_Studios "Universal
Studios").[4] In the spring of 1928, with the series going strong, Disney
asked Mintz for an increase in the budget. But Mintz instead demanded that
Walt take a 20 percent budget cut, and as leverage, he reminded Disney that
Universal owned the character, and revealed that he had already signed most of
Disney's current employees to his new contract. Angrily, Disney refused the
deal and returned to produce the final Oswald cartoons he contractually owed
Mintz. Disney was dismayed at the betrayal by his staff but determined to
restart from scratch. The new Disney Studio initially consisted of animator
[Ub Iwerks](/wiki/Ub_Iwerks "Ub Iwerks") and a loyal apprentice artist, [Les
Clark](/wiki/Les_Clark "Les Clark"), who together with [Wilfred
Jackson](/wiki/Wilfred_Jackson "Wilfred Jackson") were among the few who
remained loyal to Walt. One lesson Disney learned from the experience was to
thereafter always make sure that he owned all rights to the characters
produced by his company.

In the spring of 1928, Disney asked Ub Iwerks to start drawing up new
character ideas. Iwerks tried sketches of various animals, such as dogs and
cats, but none of these appealed to Disney. A female cow and male horse were
also rejected. They would later turn up as [Clarabelle
Cow](/wiki/Clarabelle_Cow "Clarabelle Cow") and [Horace
Horsecollar](/wiki/Horace_Horsecollar "Horace Horsecollar"). A male frog was
also rejected. It would later show up in Iwerks' own _[Flip the
Frog](/wiki/Flip_the_Frog "Flip the Frog")_ series.[5] Walt Disney got the
inspiration for Mickey Mouse from a tame mouse at his desk at Laugh-O-Gram
Studio in Kansas City, Missouri.[6] In 1925, [Hugh Harman](/wiki/Hugh_Harman
"Hugh Harman") drew some sketches of mice around a photograph of Walt Disney.
These inspired Ub Iwerks to create a new mouse character for Disney.[5]
"[Mortimer Mouse](/wiki/Mortimer_Mouse "Mortimer Mouse")" had been Disney's
original name for the character before his wife, Lillian, convinced him to
change it, and ultimately Mickey Mouse came to be.[7][8] The actor [Mickey
Rooney](/wiki/Mickey_Rooney "Mickey Rooney") claimed that, during his Mickey
McGuire days, he met cartoonist Walt Disney at the Warner Brothers studio, and
that Disney was inspired to name Mickey Mouse after him.[9] This claim,
however, has been debunked by Disney historian Jim Korkis, since at the time
of Mickey Mouse's development, Disney Studios had been located on Hyperion
Avenue for several years, and Walt Disney never kept an office or other
working space at Warner Brothers, having no professional relationship with
Warner Brothers, as the Alice Comedies and Oswald cartoons were distributed by
Universal.[10][11]

## Design

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **needs additional citations for[verification](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. _(May 2017)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Mickey_Mouse_head_and_ears.svg/220px-
Mickey_Mouse_head_and_ears.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_head_and_ears.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_head_and_ears.svg "Enlarge")

The silhouette of Mickey Mouse's head has become an iconic image

Throughout the earlier years, Mickey's design bore heavy resemblance to
[Oswald](/wiki/Oswald_the_Lucky_Rabbit "Oswald the Lucky Rabbit"), save for
the ears, nose, and tail.[12][13][14] Ub Iwerks designed Mickey's body out of
circles in order to make the character simple to animate. Disney employees
[John Hench](/wiki/John_Hench "John Hench") and [Marc
Davis](/wiki/Marc_Davis_\(animator\) "Marc Davis \(animator\)") believed that
this design was part of Mickey's success as it made him more dynamic and
appealing to audiences.

Mickey's circular design is most noticeable in his ears. In animation in the
1940s, Mickey's ears were animated in a more realistic perspective. Later,
they were drawn to always appear circular no matter which way Mickey was
facing. This made Mickey easily recognizable to audiences and made his ears an
unofficial personal trademark. The circular rule later created a dilemma for
toy creators who had to recreate a three-dimensional Mickey.

In 1938, animator [Fred Moore](/wiki/Fred_Moore_\(animator\) "Fred Moore
\(animator\)") redesigned Mickey's body away from its circular design to a
pear-shaped design. Colleague [Ward Kimball](/wiki/Ward_Kimball "Ward
Kimball") praised Moore for being the first animator to break from Mickey's
"[rubber hose](/wiki/Rubber_hose_animation "Rubber hose animation"), round
circle" design. Although Moore himself was nervous at first about changing
Mickey, Walt Disney liked the new design and told Moore "that's the way I want
Mickey to be drawn from now on."

Each of Mickey's hands has only three fingers and a thumb. Disney said that
this was both an artistic and financial decision, explaining "Artistically
five digits are too many for a mouse. His hand would look like a bunch of
bananas. Financially, not having an extra finger in each of 45,000 drawings
that make up a six and one-half minute short has saved the Studio millions."
In the film _[The Opry House](/wiki/The_Opry_House "The Opry House")_ (1929),
Mickey was first given white gloves as a way of contrasting his naturally
black hands against his black body. The use of white gloves would prove to be
an influential design for cartoon characters, particularly with later Disney
characters, but also with non-Disney characters such as [Bugs
Bunny](/wiki/Bugs_Bunny "Bugs Bunny"), [Woody
Woodpecker](/wiki/Woody_Woodpecker "Woody Woodpecker"), [Mighty
Mouse](/wiki/Mighty_Mouse "Mighty Mouse"), and [Mario](/wiki/Mario "Mario").

Mickey's eyes, as drawn in _[Plane Crazy](/wiki/Plane_Crazy "Plane Crazy")_
and _[The Gallopin' Gaucho](/wiki/The_Gallopin%27_Gaucho "The Gallopin'
Gaucho")_, were large and white with black outlines. In _[Steamboat
Willie](/wiki/Steamboat_Willie "Steamboat Willie"),_ the bottom portion of the
black outlines was removed, although the upper edges still contrasted with his
head. Mickey's eyes were later re-imagined as only consisting of the small
black dots which were originally his pupils, while what were the upper edges
of his eyes became a hairline. This is evident only when Mickey blinks. Fred
Moore later redesigned the eyes to be small white eyes with pupils and gave
his face a Caucasian skin tone instead of plain white. This new Mickey first
appeared in 1938 on the cover of a party program, and in animation the
following year with the release of _[The Pointer](/wiki/The_Pointer "The
Pointer")_.[15] Mickey is sometimes given eyebrows as seen in _[The Simple
Things](/wiki/The_Simple_Things "The Simple Things")_ (1953) and in the comic
strip, although he does not have eyebrows in his most recent appearances.

Some of Mickey's early appearance, particularly the gloves, and facial
characteristics, evolved from [blackface](/wiki/Blackface "Blackface")
caricatures used in [minstrel shows](/wiki/Minstrel_show "Minstrel
show").[16][17][18][19][20]

Besides Mickey's gloves and shoes, he typically wears only a pair of shorts
with two large buttons in the front. Before Mickey was seen regularly in color
animation, Mickey's shorts were either red or a dull blue-green. With the
advent of Mickey's color films, the shorts were always red. When Mickey is not
wearing his red shorts, he is often still wearing red clothing such as a red
bandmaster coat (_[The Band Concert](/wiki/The_Band_Concert "The Band
Concert")_ , _[The Mickey Mouse Club](/wiki/The_Mickey_Mouse_Club "The Mickey
Mouse Club")_), red overalls (_[Clock Cleaners](/wiki/Clock_Cleaners "Clock
Cleaners")_ , _[Boat Builders](/wiki/Boat_Builders_\(film\) "Boat Builders
\(film\)")_), a red cloak (_[Fantasia](/wiki/Fantasia_\(1940_film\) "Fantasia
\(1940 film\)")_ , _[Fun and Fancy Free](/wiki/Fun_and_Fancy_Free "Fun and
Fancy Free")_), a red coat (_[Squatter's
Rights](/wiki/Squatter%27s_Rights_\(film\) "Squatter's Rights \(film\)")_,
_[Mickey's Christmas Carol](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Christmas_Carol "Mickey's
Christmas Carol")_), or a red shirt (_Mickey Down Under_ , _[The Simple
Things](/wiki/The_Simple_Things "The Simple Things")_).

## Animation history

See also: [Mickey Mouse film series](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_film_series "Mickey
Mouse film series")

### Debut (1928)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4e/Steamboat-
willie.jpg/220px-Steamboat-willie.jpg)](/wiki/File:Steamboat-willie.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Steamboat-willie.jpg "Enlarge")

Mickey's first appearance in _[Steamboat Willie](/wiki/Steamboat_Willie
"Steamboat Willie")_ (1928).

Disney had Ub Iwerks secretly begin animating a new cartoon while still under
contract with Universal. The cartoon was co-directed by Walt Disney and Ub
Iwerks. Iwerks was the main [animator](/wiki/Animator "Animator") for the
short and reportedly spent six weeks working on it. In fact, Iwerks was the
main animator for every Disney short released in 1928 and 1929. Hugh Harman
and [Rudolf Ising](/wiki/Rudolf_Ising "Rudolf Ising") also assisted Disney
during those years. They had already signed their contracts with Charles
Mintz, but he was still in the process of forming his new studio and so for
the time being they were still employed by Disney. This short would be the
last they animated under this somewhat awkward situation.[21]

Mickey was first seen in a test screening of the cartoon short _[Plane
Crazy](/wiki/Plane_Crazy "Plane Crazy")_ , on May 15, 1928, but it failed to
impress the audience and to add insult to injury, Walt could not find a
distributor. Though understandably disappointed, Walt went on to produce a
second Mickey short, _[The Gallopin' Gaucho](/wiki/The_Gallopin%27_Gaucho "The
Gallopin' Gaucho")_, which was also not released for lack of a
distributor.[22]

_[Steamboat Willie](/wiki/Steamboat_Willie "Steamboat Willie")_ was first
released on November 18, 1928, in New York. It was co-directed by Walt Disney
and Ub Iwerks. Iwerks again served as the head animator, assisted by Johnny
Cannon, [Les Clark](/wiki/Les_Clark "Les Clark"), Wilfred Jackson and [Dick
Lundy](/wiki/Dick_Lundy_\(animator\) "Dick Lundy \(animator\)"). This short
was intended as a parody of [Buster Keaton](/wiki/Buster_Keaton "Buster
Keaton")'s _[Steamboat Bill, Jr.](/wiki/Steamboat_Bill,_Jr. "Steamboat Bill,
Jr.")_ , first released on May 12 of the same year. Although it was the third
Mickey cartoon produced, it was the first to find a distributor, and thus is
considered by The Disney Company as Mickey's debut. _Willie_ featured changes
to Mickey's appearance (in particular, simplifying his eyes to large dots)
that established his look for later cartoons and in numerous Walt Disney
films.[23][24]

The cartoon was not the first cartoon to feature a soundtrack connected to the
action. [Fleischer Studios](/wiki/Fleischer_Studios "Fleischer Studios"),
headed by brothers [Dave](/wiki/Dave_Fleischer "Dave Fleischer") and [Max
Fleischer](/wiki/Max_Fleischer "Max Fleischer"), had already released a number
of sound cartoons using the [DeForest](/wiki/Lee_De_Forest "Lee De Forest")
system in the mid-1920s. However, these cartoons did not keep the sound
synchronized throughout the film. For _Willie_ , Disney had the sound recorded
with a [click track](/wiki/Click_track "Click track") that kept the musicians
on the beat. This precise timing is apparent during the "Turkey in the Straw"
sequence when Mickey's actions exactly match the accompanying instruments.
Animation historians have long debated who had served as the
[composer](/wiki/Composer "Composer") for the film's original music. This role
has been variously attributed to Wilfred Jackson, [Carl
Stalling](/wiki/Carl_Stalling "Carl Stalling") and Bert Lewis, but
identification remains uncertain. Walt Disney himself was [voice
actor](/wiki/Voice_actor "Voice actor") for both Mickey and Minnie and would
remain the source of Mickey's voice through 1946 for theatrical cartoons.
[Jimmy MacDonald](/wiki/Jimmy_MacDonald_\(sound_effects_artist\) "Jimmy
MacDonald \(sound effects artist\)") took over the role in 1946, but Walt
provided Mickey's voice again from 1955 to 1959 for _[The Mickey Mouse
Club](/wiki/The_Mickey_Mouse_Club "The Mickey Mouse Club")_ television series
on [ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company").

Audiences at the time of _Steamboat Willie '_s release were reportedly
impressed by the use of sound for comedic purposes. [Sound
films](/wiki/Sound_film "Sound film") or "talkies" were still considered
innovative. The first feature-length movie with dialogue sequences, _[The Jazz
Singer](/wiki/The_Jazz_Singer_\(1927_film\) "The Jazz Singer \(1927 film\)")_
starring [Al Jolson](/wiki/Al_Jolson "Al Jolson"), was released on October 6,
1927. Within a year of its success, most United States movie theaters had
installed sound film equipment. Walt Disney apparently intended to take
advantage of this new trend and, arguably, managed to succeed. Most other
cartoon studios were still producing silent products and so were unable to
effectively act as competition to Disney. As a result, Mickey would soon
become the most prominent animated character of the time. Walt Disney soon
worked on adding sound to both _Plane Crazy_ and _The Gallopin ' Gaucho_
(which had originally been silent releases) and their new release added to
Mickey's success and popularity. A fourth Mickey short, _The Barn Dance_ , was
also put into production; however, Mickey does not actually speak until _[The
Karnival Kid](/wiki/The_Karnival_Kid "The Karnival Kid")_ in 1929 when his
first spoken words were "Hot dogs, Hot dogs!" After _Steamboat Willie_ was
released, Mickey became a close competitor to [Felix the
Cat](/wiki/Felix_the_Cat "Felix the Cat"), and his popularity would grow as he
was continuously featured in sound cartoons. By 1929, Felix would lose
popularity among theater audiences, and Pat Sullivan decided to produce all
future Felix cartoons in sound as a result.[25] Unfortunately, audiences did
not respond well to Felix's transition to sound and by 1930, Felix had faded
from the screen.[26]

### Black and white films (1929–1935)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a0/Mickey_and_Minnie_-
_Building_a_Building.png/220px-Mickey_and_Minnie_-
_Building_a_Building.png)](/wiki/File:Mickey_and_Minnie_-
_Building_a_Building.png)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_and_Minnie_-_Building_a_Building.png "Enlarge")

Mickey with [Minnie Mouse](/wiki/Minnie_Mouse "Minnie Mouse") in _[Building a
Building](/wiki/Building_a_Building "Building a Building")_ (1933).

In Mickey's early films he was often characterized not as a hero, but as an
ineffective young suitor to [Minnie Mouse](/wiki/Minnie_Mouse "Minnie Mouse").
_[The Barn Dance](/wiki/The_Barn_Dance "The Barn Dance")_ (March 14, 1929) is
the first time in which Mickey is turned down by Minnie in favor of Pete.

_[The Opry House](/wiki/The_Opry_House "The Opry House")_ (March 28, 1929) was
the first time in which Mickey wore his white gloves. Mickey wears them in
almost all of his subsequent appearances and many other characters followed
suit. The three lines on the back of Mickey's gloves represent
[darts](/wiki/Dart_\(sewing\) "Dart \(sewing\)") in the gloves' fabric
extending from between the digits of the hand, typical of glove design of the
era.

_[When the Cat's Away](/wiki/When_the_Cat%27s_Away_\(1929_film\) "When the
Cat's Away \(1929 film\)")_ (April 18, 1929), essentially a remake of the
_[Alice Comedy](/wiki/Alice_Comedies "Alice Comedies")_ , "Alice Rattled by
Rats", was an unusual appearance for Mickey. Although Mickey and Minnie still
maintained their anthropomorphic characteristics, they were depicted as the
size of regular mice and living with a community many other mice as pests in a
home. Mickey and Minnie would later appear the size of regular humans in their
own setting. In appearances with real humans, Mickey has been shown to be
about two to three feet high.[27] The next Mickey short was also unusual.
_[The Barnyard Battle](/wiki/The_Barnyard_Battle "The Barnyard Battle")_
(April 25, 1929) was the only film to depict Mickey as a soldier and also the
first to place him in combat. _[The Karnival Kid](/wiki/The_Karnival_Kid "The
Karnival Kid")_ (1929) was the first time Mickey spoke. Before this he had
only whistled, laughed, and grunted. His first words were "Hot dogs! Hot
dogs!" said while trying to sell hot dogs at a carnival. _Mickey 's Follies_
(1929) introduced the song "Minnie's Yoo-Hoo" which would become the theme
song for _Mickey Mouse_ films for the next several years. The "Minnie's Yoo-
Hoo" song sequence was also later reused with different background animation
as its own special short shown only at the commencement of 1930s theater-based
Mickey Mouse Clubs.[28][29] Mickey's dog [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(Disney\) "Pluto
\(Disney\)") first appeared as Mickey's pet in _The Moose Hunt_ (1931) after
previously appearing as Minnie's dog "Rover" in _The Picnic_ (1930).

_[The Cactus Kid](/wiki/The_Cactus_Kid "The Cactus Kid")_ (April 11, 1930) was
the last film to be animated by [Ub Iwerks](/wiki/Ub_Iwerks "Ub Iwerks") at
Disney. Shortly before the release of the film, Iwerks left to start his own
studio, bankrolled by Disney's then-distributor [Pat
Powers](/wiki/Pat_Powers_\(businessman\) "Pat Powers \(businessman\)"). Powers
and Disney had a falling out over money due Disney from the distribution deal.
It was in response to losing the right to distribute Disney's cartoons that
Powers made the deal with Iwerks, who had long harbored a desire to head his
own studio. The departure is considered a turning point in Mickey's career, as
well as that of Walt Disney. Walt lost the man who served as his closest
colleague and confidant since 1919. Mickey lost the man responsible for his
original design and for the direction or animation of several of the shorts
released till this point. Advertising for the early Mickey Mouse cartoons
credited them as "A Walt Disney Comic, drawn by Ub Iwerks". Later Disney
Company reissues of the early cartoons tend to credit Walt Disney alone.

Disney and his remaining staff continued the production of the Mickey series,
and he was able to eventually find a number of animators to replace Iwerks. As
the [Great Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression") progressed
and Felix the Cat faded from the movie screen, Mickey's popularity would rise,
and by 1932 The Mickey Mouse Club would have one million members.[30] At the
[5th Academy Awards](/wiki/5th_Academy_Awards "5th Academy Awards") in 1932,
Mickey received his first Academy Award nomination, received for _Mickey 's
Orphans_ (1931). Walt Disney also received an honorary Academy Award for the
creation of Mickey Mouse. Despite being eclipsed by the Silly Symphonies short
the _[Three Little Pigs](/wiki/Three_Little_Pigs "Three Little Pigs")_ in
1933, Mickey still maintained great popularity among theater audiences too,
until 1935, when polls showed that [Popeye](/wiki/Popeye "Popeye") was more
popular than Mickey.[31][32][33] By 1934, Mickey merchandise had earned
$600,000.00 a year.[34] In 1935, Disney began to phase out the Mickey Mouse
Clubs, due to administration problems.[35]

About this time, story artists at Disney were finding it increasingly
difficult to write material for Mickey. As he had developed into a role model
for children, they were limited in the types of gags they could make. This led
to Mickey taking more of a secondary role in some of his next films allowing
for more emphasis on other characters. In _[Orphan's
Benefit](/wiki/Orphan%27s_Benefit "Orphan's Benefit")_ (August 11, 1934)
Mickey first appeared with [Donald Duck](/wiki/Donald_Duck "Donald Duck") who
had been introduced earlier that year in the _[Silly
Symphonies](/wiki/Silly_Symphonies "Silly Symphonies")_ series. The
tempestuous duck would provide Disney with seemingly endless story ideas and
would remain a recurring character in Mickey's cartoons.

### Color films (1935–1953)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0d/Mickey_-
_The_Band_Concert.png/220px-Mickey_-
_The_Band_Concert.png)](/wiki/File:Mickey_-_The_Band_Concert.png)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_-_The_Band_Concert.png "Enlarge")

Mickey in _[The Band Concert](/wiki/The_Band_Concert "The Band Concert")_
(1935).

Mickey first appeared animated in color in _[Parade of the Award
Nominees](/wiki/Parade_of_the_Award_Nominees "Parade of the Award Nominees")_
in 1932, however, the film strip was created for the [5th Academy
Awards](/wiki/5th_Academy_Awards "5th Academy Awards") ceremony and was not
released to the public. Mickey's official first color film came in 1935 with
_[The Band Concert](/wiki/The_Band_Concert "The Band Concert")_. The
[Technicolor](/wiki/Technicolor "Technicolor") film process was used in the
film production. Here Mickey conducted the _William Tell Overture_ , but the
band is swept up by a tornado. It is said that conductor [Arturo
Toscanini](/wiki/Arturo_Toscanini "Arturo Toscanini") so loved this short
that, upon first seeing it, he asked the projectionist to run it again. In
1994, _The Band Concert_ was voted the third-greatest cartoon of all time in a
poll of animation professionals. By colorizing and partially redesigning
Mickey, Walt would put Mickey back on top once again, and Mickey would reach
popularity he never reached before as audiences now gave him more appeal.[36]
Also in 1935, Walt would receive a special award from the League of Nations
for creating Mickey.

However, by 1938, the more manic [Donald Duck](/wiki/Donald_Duck "Donald
Duck") would surpass the passive Mickey, resulting in a redesign of the mouse
between 1938 and 1940 that put Mickey at the peak of his popularity.[36] The
second half of the 1930s saw the character [Goofy](/wiki/Goofy "Goofy")
reintroduced as a series regular. Together, Mickey, Donald Duck, and Goofy
would go on several adventures together. Several of the films by the comic
trio are some of Mickey's most critically acclaimed films, including _Mickey
's Fire Brigade_ (1935), _[Moose Hunters](/wiki/Moose_Hunters "Moose
Hunters")_ (1937), _[Clock Cleaners](/wiki/Clock_Cleaners "Clock Cleaners")_
(1937), _[Lonesome Ghosts](/wiki/Lonesome_Ghosts "Lonesome Ghosts")_ (1937),
_[Boat Builders](/wiki/Boat_Builders_\(film\) "Boat Builders \(film\)")_
(1938), and _[Mickey's Trailer](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Trailer "Mickey's Trailer")_
(1938). Also during this era, Mickey would star in _[Brave Little
Tailor](/wiki/Brave_Little_Tailor "Brave Little Tailor")_ (1938), an
adaptation of _[The Valiant Little Tailor](/wiki/The_Valiant_Little_Tailor
"The Valiant Little Tailor")_ , which was nominated for an Academy Award.

Mickey was redesigned by animator [Fred Moore](/wiki/Fred_Moore_\(animator\)
"Fred Moore \(animator\)") which was first seen in _[The
Pointer](/wiki/The_Pointer "The Pointer")_ (1939). Instead of having solid
black eyes, Mickey was given white eyes with pupils, a Caucasian skin colored
face, and a pear-shaped body. In the 40's, he changed once more in _[The
Little Whirlwind](/wiki/The_Little_Whirlwind "The Little Whirlwind")_ , where
he used his trademark pants for the last time in decades, lost his tail, got
more realistic ears that changed with perspective and a different body
anatomy. But this change would only last for a short period of time before
returning to the one in "_The Pointer_ ", with the exception of his pants. In
his final theatrical cartoons in the 1950s, he was given eyebrows, which were
removed in the more recent cartoons.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f6/Mickey_-
_Fantasia.jpg/220px-Mickey_-_Fantasia.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mickey_-_Fantasia.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_-_Fantasia.jpg "Enlarge")

Mickey in _[Fantasia](/wiki/Fantasia_\(1940_film\) "Fantasia \(1940 film\)")_
(1940).

In 1940 Mickey appeared in his first feature-length film,
_[Fantasia](/wiki/Fantasia_\(1940_film\) "Fantasia \(1940 film\)")_. His
screen role as [The Sorcerer's Apprentice](/wiki/The_Sorcerer%27s_Apprentice
"The Sorcerer's Apprentice"), set to the [symphonic poem](/wiki/Symphonic_poem
"Symphonic poem") of the same name by [Paul Dukas](/wiki/Paul_Dukas "Paul
Dukas"), is perhaps the most famous segment of the film and one of Mickey's
most iconic roles. The segment features no dialogue at all, only the music.
The apprentice (Mickey), not willing to do his chores, puts on the sorcerer's
magic hat after the sorcerer goes to bed and casts a spell on a broom, which
causes the broom to come to life and perform the most tiring chore—filling up
a deep well using two buckets of water. When the well eventually overflows,
Mickey finds himself unable to control the broom, leading to a near-flood.
After the segment ends, Mickey is seen in silhouette shaking hands with
[Leopold Stokowski](/wiki/Leopold_Stokowski "Leopold Stokowski"), who conducts
all the music heard in _Fantasia_. Mickey has often been pictured in the red
robe and blue sorcerer's hat in merchandising. It was also featured into the
climax of [Fantasmic!](/wiki/Fantasmic! "Fantasmic!"), an attraction at the
Disney theme parks.

After 1940, Mickey's popularity would decline until his 1955 re-emergence as a
daily children's television personality.[37] Despite this, the character
continued to appear regularly in animated shorts until 1943 (winning his only
competitive Academy Award—with canine companion [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(Disney\)
"Pluto \(Disney\)")—for a short subject, _Lend a Paw_) and again from 1946 to
1952.

The last regular installment of the _Mickey Mouse_ film series came in 1953
with _[The Simple Things](/wiki/The_Simple_Things "The Simple Things")_ in
which Mickey and Pluto go fishing and are pestered by a flock of seagulls.

### Television and later films

In the 1950s, Mickey became more known for his appearances on television,
particularly with _The Mickey Mouse Club_. Many of his theatrical cartoon
shorts were rereleased on television series such as _Ink & Paint Club_,
various forms of the [Walt Disney anthology television
series](/wiki/Walt_Disney_anthology_television_series "Walt Disney anthology
television series"), and on home video. Mickey returned to theatrical
animation in 1983 with _[Mickey's Christmas
Carol](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Christmas_Carol "Mickey's Christmas Carol")_, an
adaptation of [Charles Dickens](/wiki/Charles_Dickens "Charles Dickens")' _[A
Christmas Carol](/wiki/A_Christmas_Carol "A Christmas Carol")_ in which Mickey
played [Bob Cratchit](/wiki/Bob_Cratchit "Bob Cratchit"). This was followed up
in 1990 with _[The Prince and the
Pauper](/wiki/The_Prince_and_the_Pauper_\(1990_film\) "The Prince and the
Pauper \(1990 film\)")_.

Throughout the decades, Mickey Mouse competed with [Warner
Bros.](/wiki/Warner_Bros. "Warner Bros.")' [Bugs Bunny](/wiki/Bugs_Bunny "Bugs
Bunny") for animated popularity. But in 1988, the two rivals finally shared
screen time in the [Robert Zemeckis](/wiki/Robert_Zemeckis "Robert Zemeckis")
[Disney](/wiki/Disney "Disney")/[Amblin](/wiki/Amblin "Amblin") film _[Who
Framed Roger Rabbit](/wiki/Who_Framed_Roger_Rabbit "Who Framed Roger
Rabbit")_. Disney and Warner signed an agreement stating that each character
had the same amount of screen time in the scene.

Similar to his animated inclusion into a live-action film on _Roger Rabbit_ ,
Mickey made a featured cameo appearance in the 1990 television special _[The
Muppets at Walt Disney World](/wiki/The_Muppets_at_Walt_Disney_World "The
Muppets at Walt Disney World")_ where he met [Kermit the
Frog](/wiki/Kermit_the_Frog "Kermit the Frog"). The two are established in the
story as having been old friends. [The Muppets](/wiki/The_Muppets "The
Muppets") have otherwise spoofed and referenced Mickey over a dozen times
since the 1970s. Eventually, The Muppets were purchased by the Walt Disney
Company in 2004.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a3/Mickey_-
_House_of_Mouse.png/220px-Mickey_-_House_of_Mouse.png)](/wiki/File:Mickey_-
_House_of_Mouse.png)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_-_House_of_Mouse.png "Enlarge")

Mickey in _[Disney's House of Mouse](/wiki/Disney%27s_House_of_Mouse "Disney's
House of Mouse")_ (2001–2003).

His most recent theatrical cartoon short was 2013's _[Get a
Horse!](/wiki/Get_a_Horse! "Get a Horse!")_ which was preceded by 1995's
_[Runaway Brain](/wiki/Runaway_Brain "Runaway Brain")_ , while from 1999 to
2004, he appeared in direct-to-video features like _[Mickey's Once Upon a
Christmas](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Once_Upon_a_Christmas "Mickey's Once Upon a
Christmas")_, _[Mickey, Donald, Goofy: The Three
Musketeers](/wiki/Mickey,_Donald,_Goofy:_The_Three_Musketeers "Mickey, Donald,
Goofy: The Three Musketeers")_ and the computer-animated _[Mickey's Twice Upon
a Christmas](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Twice_Upon_a_Christmas "Mickey's Twice Upon a
Christmas")_.

Many television series have centered on Mickey, such as the ABC shows _[Mickey
Mouse Works](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_Works "Mickey Mouse Works")_ (1999–2000),
_[Disney's House of Mouse](/wiki/Disney%27s_House_of_Mouse "Disney's House of
Mouse")_ (2001–2003), [Disney Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel "Disney
Channel")'s _[Mickey Mouse Clubhouse](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_Clubhouse "Mickey
Mouse Clubhouse")_ (2006–2016), and _[Mickey and the Roadster
Racers](/wiki/Mickey_and_the_Roadster_Racers "Mickey and the Roadster
Racers")_ (2017–). Prior to all these, Mickey was also featured as an [unseen
character](/wiki/Unseen_character "Unseen character") in the
_[Bonkers](/wiki/Bonkers_\(TV_series\) "Bonkers \(TV series\)")_ episode "You
Oughta Be In Toons".

Mickey has recently been announced to star in two films. One is being based on
the [Magic Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom "Magic Kingdom") theme park at the
[Walt Disney World Resort](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World_Resort "Walt Disney World
Resort"), while the other is a film idea pitched by [Walt Disney Animation
Studios](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios "Walt Disney Animation Studios")
veteran [Burny Mattinson](/wiki/Burny_Mattinson "Burny Mattinson") centering
on Mickey, Donald, and Goofy.[38]

Since June 28, 2013, [Disney Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel "Disney Channel")
has been airing new 3-minute _[Mickey Mouse](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_\(TV_series\)
"Mickey Mouse \(TV series\)")_ shorts, with animator [Paul
Rudish](/wiki/Paul_Rudish "Paul Rudish") at the helm, incorporating elements
of Mickey's late twenties-early thirties look with a contemporary twist.[39]
The creative team behind the [2017 _DuckTales_
reboot](/wiki/DuckTales_\(2017_TV_series\) "DuckTales \(2017 TV series\)") had
hoped to have Mickey Mouse in the series, but this idea was rejected by Disney
executives.[40]

## Voice actors

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Walt_disney_portrait.jpg/220px-
Walt_disney_portrait.jpg)](/wiki/File:Walt_disney_portrait.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Walt_disney_portrait.jpg "Enlarge")

Walt Disney (1901–1966), the co-creator of Mickey Mouse and founder of [The
Walt Disney Company](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company"),
was the original voice of Mickey.

A large part of Mickey's screen persona is his famously shy,
[falsetto](/wiki/Falsetto "Falsetto") voice. From 1928 onward, Mickey was
voiced by Walt Disney himself, a task in which Disney took great personal
pride. However, by 1946, Disney was becoming too busy with running the studio
to do regular voice work which meant he could not do Mickey's voice on a
regular basis anymore. It is also speculated that his [cigarette
habit](/wiki/Tobacco_smoking "Tobacco smoking") had damaged his voice over the
years. After recording the _Mickey and the Beanstalk_ section of _[Fun and
Fancy Free](/wiki/Fun_and_Fancy_Free "Fun and Fancy Free")_ , Mickey's voice
was handed over to veteran Disney musician and actor [Jimmy
MacDonald](/wiki/Jimmy_MacDonald_\(sound_effects_artist\) "Jimmy MacDonald
\(sound effects artist\)"). MacDonald voiced Mickey in the remainder of the
theatrical shorts and for various television and publicity projects up until
his retirement in 1977, although Walt would reprise Mickey's voice
occasionally until his passing in 1966, such as in the introductions to the
original 1955–1959 run of _[The Mickey Mouse Club](/wiki/The_Mickey_Mouse_Club
"The Mickey Mouse Club")_ TV series, the "Fourth Anniversary Show" episode of
the [Disneyland](/wiki/Disneyland "Disneyland") TV series that aired on
September 11, 1958 and the _Disneyland USA at Radio City Music Hall_ show from
1962.[41]

Composer [Carl W. Stalling](/wiki/Carl_W._Stalling "Carl W. Stalling") was the
very first person to provide lines for Mickey in the 1929 short _[The Karnival
Kid](/wiki/The_Karnival_Kid "The Karnival Kid")_. [Clarence
Nash](/wiki/Clarence_Nash "Clarence Nash") voiced Mickey in the 1934 short
_[The Dognapper](/wiki/The_Dognapper "The Dognapper")_ since Walt was
traveling in Europe at the time and was unavailable to record his lines for
Mickey for that short. Along with Disney, J. Donald Wilson and Joe Twerp
provided the voice in 1938 broadcasts of _[The Mickey Mouse Theater of the
Air](/wiki/The_Mickey_Mouse_Theater_of_the_Air "The Mickey Mouse Theater of
the Air")_.[42] [Stan Freberg](/wiki/Stan_Freberg "Stan Freberg") voiced
Mickey in the Freberg-produced record _Mickey Mouse 's Birthday Party_. [Alan
Young](/wiki/Alan_Young "Alan Young") voiced Mickey in the Disneyland record
album _An Adaptation of Dickens ' Christmas Carol, Performed by The Walt
Disney Players_ in 1974, which would be the first and only time that Alan
Young voiced him.[43][44]

The 1983 short film _[Mickey's Christmas
Carol](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Christmas_Carol "Mickey's Christmas Carol")_ marked
the theatrical debut of [Wayne Allwine](/wiki/Wayne_Allwine "Wayne Allwine")
as Mickey Mouse, who was the official voice of Mickey from 1977 until his
death in 2009.[45] Allwine once recounted something MacDonald had told him
about voicing Mickey: "The main piece of advice that Jim gave me about Mickey
helped me keep things in perspective. He said, 'Just remember kid, you're only
filling in for the boss.' And that's the way he treated doing Mickey for years
and years. From Walt, and now from Jimmy."[46] In 1991, Allwine married [Russi
Taylor](/wiki/Russi_Taylor "Russi Taylor"), the voice of [Minnie
Mouse](/wiki/Minnie_Mouse "Minnie Mouse") since 1986.

Les Perkins did the voice of Mickey in two TV specials, "Down and Out with
Donald Duck" and "DTV Valentine", in the mid-1980s. [Peter
Renaday](/wiki/Peter_Renaday "Peter Renaday") voiced Mickey in the 1980s
Disney albums _Yankee Doodle Mickey_ and _Mickey Mouse Splashdance_.[47][48]
He also provided his voice for _[The Talking Mickey
Mouse](/wiki/The_Talking_Mickey_Mouse "The Talking Mickey Mouse")_ toy in
1986.[49][50] [Quinton Flynn](/wiki/Quinton_Flynn "Quinton Flynn") briefly
filled in for Allwine as the voice of Mickey in a few episodes of the first
season of _[Mickey Mouse Works](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_Works "Mickey Mouse
Works")_ whenever Allwine was unavailable to record.[51]

[Bret Iwan](/wiki/Bret_Iwan "Bret Iwan"), a former
[Hallmark](/wiki/Hallmark_Cards "Hallmark Cards") greeting card artist, is the
current voice of Mickey. Iwan was originally cast as an understudy for Allwine
due to the latter’s declining health; however, Allwine died before Iwan could
meet him and Iwan became the new official voice of the character. Iwan’s early
recordings in 2009 included work for the [Disney Cruise
Line](/wiki/Disney_Cruise_Line "Disney Cruise Line"), Mickey toys, the Disney
theme parks and the [Disney on Ice: Celebrations!](/wiki/Disney_on_Ice "Disney
on Ice") ice show.[52] He directly replaced Allwine as Mickey for the
[_Kingdom Hearts_ video game series](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts "Kingdom Hearts")
and the TV series _[Mickey Mouse Clubhouse](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_Clubhouse
"Mickey Mouse Clubhouse")_. His first video game voice-over of Mickey Mouse
can be heard in _[Kingdom Hearts: Birth by
Sleep](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts:_Birth_by_Sleep "Kingdom Hearts: Birth by
Sleep")_. Iwan also became the first voice actor to portray Mickey during
Disney’s rebranding of the character, providing the vocal effects of Mickey in
_[Epic Mickey](/wiki/Epic_Mickey "Epic Mickey")_ as well as his voice in
_[Epic Mickey 2: The Power of Two](/wiki/Epic_Mickey_2:_The_Power_of_Two "Epic
Mickey 2: The Power of Two")_ and the remake of _[Castle of
Illusion](/wiki/Castle_of_Illusion_Starring_Mickey_Mouse_\(2013_video_game\)
"Castle of Illusion Starring Mickey Mouse \(2013 video game\)")_. Despite Iwan
being Mickey's primary voice actor, the character's voice is provided by
[Chris Diamantopoulos](/wiki/Chris_Diamantopoulos "Chris Diamantopoulos") in
the [2013 animated series](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_\(TV_series\) "Mickey Mouse \(TV
series\)"),[53] as the producers were looking for a voice closer to Walt
Disney’s portrayal of the character in order to match the vintage look of that
series.[54]

## Mickey in comics

Main article: [Mickey Mouse (comic book)](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_\(comic_book\)
"Mickey Mouse \(comic book\)")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/94/Mickey_Mouse_-
_Blaggard_Castle.png/220px-Mickey_Mouse_-
_Blaggard_Castle.png)](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_-_Blaggard_Castle.png)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_-_Blaggard_Castle.png "Enlarge")

Mickey and Horace Horsecollar from the _Mickey Mouse_ daily strip; created by
[Floyd Gottfredson](/wiki/Floyd_Gottfredson "Floyd Gottfredson") and published
December 1932.

Mickey first appeared in comics after he had appeared in 15 commercially
successful animated shorts and was easily recognized by the public. Walt
Disney was approached by [King Features
Syndicate](/wiki/King_Features_Syndicate "King Features Syndicate") with the
offer to license Mickey and his [supporting
characters](/wiki/Supporting_character "Supporting character") for use in a
comic strip. Disney accepted and Mickey made his first comic strip appearance
on January 13, 1930. The comical plot was credited to Disney himself, art to
Ub Iwerks and inking to [Win Smith](/wiki/Win_Smith "Win Smith"). The first
week or so of the strip featured a loose adaptation of "_Plane Crazy_ ".
Minnie soon became the first addition to the cast. The strips first released
between January 13, 1930, and March 31, 1930, has been occasionally reprinted
in [comic book](/wiki/Comic_book "Comic book") form under the collective title
_" Lost on a Desert Island_". Animation historian Jim Korkis notes "After the
eighteenth strip, Iwerks left and his inker, Win Smith, continued drawing the
gag-a-day format..."[55]

In early 1930, after Iwerks' departure, Disney was at first content to
continue scripting the Mickey Mouse comic strip, assigning the art to Win
Smith. However, Disney's focus had always been in animation and Smith was soon
assigned with the scripting as well. Smith was apparently discontent at the
prospect of having to script, draw, and ink a series by himself as evidenced
by his sudden resignation.

Disney then searched for a replacement among the remaining staff of the
Studio. He selected [Floyd Gottfredson](/wiki/Floyd_Gottfredson "Floyd
Gottfredson"), a recently hired employee. At the time Gottfredson was
reportedly eager to work in animation and somewhat reluctant to accept his new
assignment. Disney had to assure him the assignment was only temporary and
that he would eventually return to animation. Gottfredson accepted and ended
up holding this "temporary" assignment from May 5, 1930, to November 15, 1975.

Walt Disney's last script for the strip appeared May 17, 1930.[55]
Gottfredson's first task was to finish the storyline Disney had started on
April 1, 1930. The storyline was completed on September 20, 1930, and later
reprinted in comic book form as _Mickey Mouse in Death Valley_. This early
adventure expanded the cast of the strip which to this point only included
Mickey and Minnie. Among the characters who had their first comic strip
appearances in this story were Clarabelle Cow, Horace Horsecollar, and [Black
Pete](/wiki/Pete_\(Disney\) "Pete \(Disney\)") as well as the debuts of
corrupted [lawyer](/wiki/Lawyer "Lawyer") [Sylvester
Shyster](/wiki/Sylvester_Shyster "Sylvester Shyster") and Minnie's uncle
[Mortimer Mouse](/wiki/Mortimer_Mouse "Mortimer Mouse"). The Death Valley
narrative was followed by _Mr. Slicker and the Egg Robbers_ , first printed
between September 22 and December 26, 1930, which introduced [Marcus
Mouse](/wiki/Marcus_Mouse "Marcus Mouse") and his wife as Minnie's parents.

Starting with these two early comic strip stories, Mickey's versions in
animation and comics are considered to have diverged from each other. While
Disney and his [cartoon](/wiki/Cartoon "Cartoon") shorts would continue to
focus on [comedy](/wiki/Comedy "Comedy"), the comic strip effectively combined
comedy and adventure. This adventurous version of Mickey would continue to
appear in comic strips and later comic books throughout the 20th and into the
21st century.

Floyd Gottfredson left his mark with stories such as _Mickey Mouse Joins the
Foreign Legion_ (1936) and _The Gleam_ (1942). He also created the [Phantom
Blot](/wiki/Phantom_Blot "Phantom Blot"), [Eega Beeva](/wiki/Eega_Beeva "Eega
Beeva"), Morty and Ferdie, Captain Churchmouse, and Butch. Besides Gottfredson
artists for the strip over the years included Roman Arambula, Rick Hoover,
[Manuel Gonzales](/wiki/Manuel_Gonzales "Manuel Gonzales"), [Carson Van
Osten](/wiki/Carson_Van_Osten "Carson Van Osten"), Jim Engel, Bill Wright, Ted
Thwailes and [Daan Jippes](/wiki/Daan_Jippes "Daan Jippes"); writers included
[Ted Osborne](/wiki/Ted_Osborne "Ted Osborne"), [Merrill De
Maris](/wiki/Merrill_De_Maris "Merrill De Maris"), [Bill
Walsh](/wiki/Bill_Walsh_\(producer\) "Bill Walsh \(producer\)"), Dick Shaw,
[Roy Williams](/wiki/Roy_Williams_\(artist\) "Roy Williams \(artist\)"), Del
Connell, and [Floyd Norman](/wiki/Floyd_Norman "Floyd Norman").

The next artist to leave his mark on the character was [Paul
Murry](/wiki/Paul_Murry "Paul Murry") in [Dell Comics](/wiki/Dell_Comics "Dell
Comics"). His first Mickey tale appeared in 1950 but Mickey did not become a
specialty until Murry's first serial for _[Walt Disney's Comics and
Stories](/wiki/Walt_Disney%27s_Comics_and_Stories "Walt Disney's Comics and
Stories")_ in 1953 ("The Last Resort"). In the same period, [Romano
Scarpa](/wiki/Romano_Scarpa "Romano Scarpa") in Italy for the magazine
_Topolino_ began to revitalize Mickey in stories that brought back the
[Phantom Blot](/wiki/Phantom_Blot "Phantom Blot") and [Eega
Beeva](/wiki/Eega_Beeva "Eega Beeva") along with new creations such as the
Atomo Bleep-Bleep. While the stories at [Western
Publishing](/wiki/Western_Publishing "Western Publishing") during the [Silver
Age](/wiki/Silver_Age_of_Comic_Books "Silver Age of Comic Books") emphasized
Mickey as a detective in the style of [Sherlock Holmes](/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes
"Sherlock Holmes"), in the modern era several editors and creators have
consciously undertaken to depict a more vigorous Mickey in the mold of the
classic Gottfredson adventures. This renaissance has been spearheaded by
[Byron Erickson](/wiki/Byron_Erickson "Byron Erickson"), [David
Gerstein](/wiki/David_Gerstein "David Gerstein"), [Noel Van
Horn](/wiki/Noel_Van_Horn "Noel Van Horn"), [Michael T.
Gilbert](/wiki/Michael_T._Gilbert "Michael T. Gilbert") and [César
Ferioli](/wiki/C%C3%A9sar_Ferioli "César Ferioli").

In Europe, Mickey Mouse became the main attraction of a number of comics
magazines, the most famous being _[Topolino](/wiki/Topolino "Topolino")_ in
Italy from 1932 on, _[Le Journal de Mickey](/wiki/Le_Journal_de_Mickey "Le
Journal de Mickey")_ in France from 1934 on, _[Don
Miki](/w/index.php?title=Don_Miki&action=edit&redlink=1 "Don Miki \(page does
not exist\)")_ in Spain and the Greek _[Miky Maous](/wiki/Miky_Maous "Miky
Maous")_.

Mickey was the main character for the series _[MM Mickey Mouse Mystery
Magazine](/wiki/MM_Mickey_Mouse_Mystery_Magazine "MM Mickey Mouse Mystery
Magazine")_ , published in Italy from 1999 to 2001.

In 2006, he appeared in the Italian fantasy comic saga _[Wizards of
Mickey](/wiki/Wizards_of_Mickey "Wizards of Mickey")_.

In 1958, Mickey Mouse was introduced to the Arab world through another comic
book called “Sameer”. He became very popular in Egypt and got a comic book
with his name. Mickey’s comics in Egypt are licensed by Disney and were
published since 1959 by “Dar Al-Hilal” and they were success, however Dar Al-
Hilal stopped the publication in 2003 because of problems with Disney. The
comics were re-released by "Nahdat Masr" in 2004 and the first issues were
sold out in less than 8 hours.[56]

## Merchandising

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1f/Mickey_Mouse_Ingersoll_watch_1933.jpg/120px-
Mickey_Mouse_Ingersoll_watch_1933.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_Ingersoll_watch_1933.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_Ingersoll_watch_1933.jpg "Enlarge")

A 1933 [Ingersoll](/wiki/Ingersoll_Watch_Company "Ingersoll Watch Company")
Mickey Mouse wrist watch.

Since his early years, Mickey Mouse has been licensed by Disney to appear on
many different kinds of merchandise. Mickey was produced as plush toys and
figurines, and Mickey's image has graced almost everything from T-shirts to
lunchboxes. Largely responsible for Disney merchandising in the 1930s was [Kay
Kamen](/wiki/Kay_Kamen "Kay Kamen") (1892–1949) who was called a "stickler for
quality." Kamen was recognized by The Walt Disney Company as having a
significant part in Mickey's rise to stardom and was named a [Disney
Legend](/wiki/Disney_Legend "Disney Legend") in 1998.[57] At the time of his
80th-anniversary celebration in 2008, _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time
\(magazine\)")_ declared Mickey Mouse one of the world's most recognized
characters, even when compared against [Santa Claus](/wiki/Santa_Claus "Santa
Claus").[58] Disney officials have stated that 98% of children aged 3–11
around the world are at least aware of the character.[58]

Mickey was most famously featured on wrist watches and alarm clocks, typically
utilizing his hands as the actual hands on the face of the clock. The first
Mickey Mouse watches were manufactured in 1933 by the [Ingersoll Watch
Company](/wiki/Ingersoll_Watch_Company "Ingersoll Watch Company"). The seconds
were indicated by a turning disk below Mickey. The first Mickey watch was sold
at the [Century of Progress](/wiki/Century_of_Progress "Century of Progress")
in Chicago, 1933 for $3.75. Mickey Mouse watches have been sold by other
companies and designers throughout the years, including
[Timex](/wiki/Timex_Group_USA "Timex Group USA"), Elgin, Helbros, Bradley,
Lorus, and [Gérald Genta](/wiki/G%C3%A9rald_Genta "Gérald Genta")[59] The
fictional character [Robert Langdon](/wiki/Robert_Langdon "Robert Langdon")
from Dan Brown's novels was said to wear a Mickey Mouse watch as a reminder
"to stay young at heart."[60]

In 1989, [Milton Bradley](/wiki/Milton_Bradley "Milton Bradley") released the
electronic talking game titled _Mickey Says_ , with three modes featuring
Mickey Mouse as its host. Mickey also appeared in other toys and games,
including the [Worlds of Wonder](/wiki/Worlds_of_Wonder_\(toy_company\)
"Worlds of Wonder \(toy company\)") released _[The Talking Mickey
Mouse](/wiki/The_Talking_Mickey_Mouse "The Talking Mickey Mouse")_.

[Fisher-Price](/wiki/Fisher-Price "Fisher-Price") has recently produced a line
of talking animatronic Mickey dolls including "Dance Star Mickey" (2010)[61]
and "Rock Star Mickey" (2011).[62]

In total, approximately 40% of Disney's revenues for consumer products are
derived from Mickey Mouse merchandise, with revenues peaking in 1997.[58]

## Mickey at the Disney parks

[![HKMickeyMinnieMainStreetSummer07.JPG](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/8/81/HKMickeyMinnieMainStreetSummer07.JPG/200px-
HKMickeyMinnieMainStreetSummer07.JPG)](/wiki/File:HKMickeyMinnieMainStreetSummer07.JPG)[![Disneyland
park - Anaheim Los Angeles California USA
\(9894366226\).jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Disneyland_park_-
_Anaheim_Los_Angeles_California_USA_%289894366226%29.jpg/200px-
Disneyland_park_-
_Anaheim_Los_Angeles_California_USA_%289894366226%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Disneyland_park_-
_Anaheim_Los_Angeles_California_USA_\(9894366226\).jpg)

Minnie and Mickey at [Hong Kong Disneyland](/wiki/Hong_Kong_Disneyland "Hong
Kong Disneyland") (left) and Mickey's house at [Mickey's
Toontown](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Toontown "Mickey's Toontown") (right)

As the official Walt Disney mascot, Mickey has played a central role in the
[Disney parks](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Parks_and_Resorts "Walt Disney Parks and
Resorts") since the opening of [Disneyland](/wiki/Disneyland "Disneyland") in
1955. As with other characters, Mickey is often portrayed by a non-speaking
costumed actor. In this form, he has participated in ceremonies and countless
parades. A popular activity with guests is getting to meet and pose for
photographs with the mouse. As of the presidency of [Barack
Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack Obama") (who jokingly referred to him as "a
world leader who has bigger ears than me")[63] Mickey has met every U.S.
President since [Harry Truman](/wiki/Harry_Truman "Harry Truman"), with the
exception of [Lyndon B. Johnson](/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B.
Johnson").[14]

Mickey also features in several specific attractions at the Disney parks.
[Mickey's Toontown](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Toontown "Mickey's Toontown") (Disneyland
and [Tokyo Disneyland](/wiki/Tokyo_Disneyland "Tokyo Disneyland")) is a themed
land which is a recreation of Mickey's neighborhood. Buildings are built in a
cartoon style and guests can visit
[Mickey](/wiki/Mickey%27s_House_and_Meet_Mickey "Mickey's House and Meet
Mickey") or Minnie's houses, [Donald Duck](/wiki/Donald_Duck "Donald Duck")'s
boat, or [Goofy](/wiki/Goofy "Goofy")'s garage. This is a common place to meet
the characters.[64]

[Mickey's PhilharMagic](/wiki/Mickey%27s_PhilharMagic "Mickey's PhilharMagic")
(Magic Kingdom, Tokyo Disneyland, [Hong Kong
Disneyland](/wiki/Hong_Kong_Disneyland "Hong Kong Disneyland")) is a [4D
film](/wiki/4D_film "4D film") which features Mickey in the familiar role of
symphony conductor. At [Main Street Cinema](/wiki/Main_Street_Cinema "Main
Street Cinema") several of Mickey's short films are shown on a rotating basis;
the sixth film is always _[Steamboat Willie](/wiki/Steamboat_Willie "Steamboat
Willie")_. Mickey plays a central role in _[Fantasmic!](/wiki/Fantasmic!
"Fantasmic!")_ ([Disneyland Resort](/wiki/Disneyland_Resort "Disneyland
Resort"), [Disney's Hollywood Studios](/wiki/Disney%27s_Hollywood_Studios
"Disney's Hollywood Studios")) a live nighttime show which famously features
Mickey in his role as the [Sorcerer's Apprentice](/wiki/Fantasia_\(1940_film\)
"Fantasia \(1940 film\)"). Mickey was also a central character in the now-
defunct [Mickey Mouse Revue](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_Revue "Mickey Mouse Revue")
(Magic Kingdom, Tokyo Disneyland) which was an indoor show featuring
animatronic characters. Mickey's face currently graces the [Mickey's Fun
Wheel](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Fun_Wheel "Mickey's Fun Wheel") at [Disney California
Adventure Park](/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure_Park "Disney California
Adventure Park"), where a figure of him also stands on top of [Silly Symphony
Swings](/wiki/Silly_Symphony_Swings "Silly Symphony Swings").

In addition to Mickey's overt presence in the parks, numerous images of him
are also subtly included in sometimes unexpected places. This phenomenon is
known as "[Hidden Mickey](/wiki/Hidden_Mickey "Hidden Mickey")", involving
hidden images in Disney films, theme parks, and merchandise.

Main article: [List of Disney video games (Mickey Mouse
Series)](/wiki/List_of_Disney_video_games#Mickey_Mouse_Series "List of Disney
video games")

Like many popular characters, Mickey has starred in many [video

"Disney's Magical Quest")_ on the [Super Nintendo Entertainment

Entertainment System"), _[Castle of Illusion Starring Mickey
Mouse](/wiki/Castle_of_Illusion_Starring_Mickey_Mouse "Castle of Illusion

Drive"), _[Mickey Mouse: Magic Wands!](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse:_Magic_Wands!

[ported](/wiki/Porting "Porting") to the [Game Boy
Advance](/wiki/Game_Boy_Advance "Game Boy Advance"), while Mickey made his
[sixth generation
era](/wiki/History_of_video_game_consoles_\(sixth_generation\) "History of
video game consoles \(sixth generation\)") debut in _[Disney's Magical Mirror
Starring Mickey Mouse](/wiki/Disney%27s_Magical_Mirror_Starring_Mickey_Mouse

Hearts](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts "Kingdom Hearts")_ series, as the king of [Disney
Castle](/wiki/Universe_of_Kingdom_Hearts#Disney_Castle "Universe of Kingdom

"Sora \(Kingdom Hearts\)"). King Mickey wields the [Keyblade](/wiki/Keyblade
"Keyblade"), a weapon in the form of a key that has the power to open any lock
and combat darkness. _[Epic Mickey](/wiki/Epic_Mickey "Epic Mickey")_ ,
featuring a darker version of the Disney universe, was released in 2010 for
the [Wii](/wiki/Wii "Wii"). The game is part of an effort by [The Walt Disney
Company](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company") to re-brand
the Mickey Mouse character by moving away from his current squeaky clean image
and reintroducing the mischievous side of his personality.[3]

## Awards and honors

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Mickey_Mouse_star_in_Walk_of_Fame.jpg/220px-
Mickey_Mouse_star_in_Walk_of_Fame.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_star_in_Walk_of_Fame.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mickey_Mouse_star_in_Walk_of_Fame.jpg "Enlarge")

Mickey's star on the [Hollywood Walk of Fame](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame
"Hollywood Walk of Fame").

Mickey Mouse has received ten nominations for the [Academy Award for Best
Animated Short Film](/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Animated_Short_Film "Academy
Award for Best Animated Short Film"). These are _Mickey 's Orphans_ (1931),
_[Building a Building](/wiki/Building_a_Building "Building a Building")_
(1933), _[Brave Little Tailor](/wiki/Brave_Little_Tailor "Brave Little
Tailor")_ (1938), _The Pointer_ (1939), _[Lend a Paw](/wiki/Lend_a_Paw "Lend a
Paw")_ (1941), _[Squatter's Rights](/wiki/Squatter%27s_Rights_\(film\)
"Squatter's Rights \(film\)")_ (1946), _[Mickey and the
Seal](/wiki/Mickey_and_the_Seal "Mickey and the Seal")_ (1948), _[Mickey's
Christmas Carol](/wiki/Mickey%27s_Christmas_Carol "Mickey's Christmas Carol")_
(1983), _[Runaway Brain](/wiki/Runaway_Brain "Runaway Brain")_ (1995), and
_[Get a Horse!](/wiki/Get_a_Horse! "Get a Horse!")_ (2013). Among these, _Lend
a Paw_ was the only film to actually win the award. Additionally, in 1932 Walt
Disney received an honorary Academy Award in recognition of Mickey's creation
and popularity.

In 1994, four of Mickey's cartoons were included in the book _[The 50 Greatest
Cartoons](/wiki/The_50_Greatest_Cartoons "The 50 Greatest Cartoons")_ which
listed the greatest cartoons of all time as voted by members of the animation
field. The films were _[The Band Concert](/wiki/The_Band_Concert "The Band
Concert")_ (#3), _[Steamboat Willie](/wiki/Steamboat_Willie "Steamboat
Willie")_ (#13), _Brave Little Tailor_ (#26), and _[Clock
Cleaners](/wiki/Clock_Cleaners "Clock Cleaners")_ (#27).

On November 18, 1978, in honor of his 50th anniversary, Mickey became the
first cartoon character to have a star on the [Hollywood Walk of
Fame](/wiki/Hollywood_Walk_of_Fame "Hollywood Walk of Fame"). The star is
located on 6925 Hollywood Blvd.

[Melbourne (Australia)](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne") runs the annual
[Moomba](/wiki/Moomba "Moomba") festival street procession and appointed
Mickey Mouse as their _King of Moomba_ (1977).[65]:17–22 Although immensely
popular with children, there was controversy with the appointment: some
Melburnians wanted a 'home-grown' choice, e.g. [Blinky Bill](/wiki/Blinky_Bill
"Blinky Bill"); when it was revealed that Patricia O'Carroll (from
Disneyland's Disney on Parade show) was performing the mouse, Australian
newspapers reported "Mickey Mouse is really a girl!"[65]:19–20

Mickey was the [Grand Marshal of the Tournament of Roses
Parade](/wiki/Grand_Marshal_of_the_Tournament_of_Roses_Parade "Grand Marshal
of the Tournament of Roses Parade") on New Year's Day 2005. He was the first
cartoon character to receive the honor and only the second fictional character
after [Kermit the Frog](/wiki/Kermit_the_Frog "Kermit the Frog") in 1996.

## Social impact

### Use in politics

In the United States, [protest votes](/wiki/Protest_votes "Protest votes") are
often made in order to indicate dissatisfaction with the slate of candidates
presented on a particular ballot or to highlight the inadequacies of a
particular voting procedure. Since most states' electoral systems do not
provide for blank balloting or a choice of "[None of the
Above](/wiki/None_of_the_Above "None of the Above")", most protest votes take
the form of a clearly non-serious candidate's name entered as a [write-in
vote](/wiki/Write-in_vote "Write-in vote"). Mickey Mouse is often selected for
this purpose.[66][67] As an election supervisor in Georgia observed, "If
[Mickey Mouse] doesn’t get votes in our election, it’s a bad election."[68]
The earliest known mention of Mickey Mouse as a write-in candidate dates back
to the 1932 [New York City mayoral
elections](/wiki/New_York_City_mayoral_elections "New York City mayoral
elections").[69]

Mickey Mouse's name has also been known to appear fraudulently on voter
registration lists, such as in the [2008 U.S. Presidential
Election](/wiki/2008_U.S._Presidential_Election "2008 U.S. Presidential
Election").[70][71]

### Pejorative use of Mickey's name

"Mickey Mouse" is a slang expression meaning small-time, amateurish or
trivial. In the United Kingdom and Ireland, it also means poor quality or
counterfeit. However, in parts of Australia it can mean excellent or very good
(rhyming slang for "grouse").[72] Examples of the former two of the three
usages include the following:

  * In _[The Godfather Part II](/wiki/The_Godfather_Part_II "The Godfather Part II")_ , [Fredo](/wiki/Fredo_Corleone "Fredo Corleone")'s justification of betraying Michael is that his orders in the family usually were "Send Fredo off to do this, send Fredo off to do that! Let Fredo take care of some Mickey Mouse nightclub somewhere!" as opposed to more meaningful tasks.
  * In an early episode of the 1978–82 [sitcom](/wiki/Sitcom "Sitcom") _[Mork& Mindy](/wiki/Mork_%26_Mindy "Mork & Mindy")_, Mork stated that [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto "Pluto") was "a Mickey Mouse planet", referring to the future [dwarf planet](/wiki/Dwarf_planet "Dwarf planet") having the same name as Mickey's pet dog [Pluto](/wiki/Pluto_\(Disney\) "Pluto \(Disney\)"). Actually, the planet was named shortly before the dog was.
  * In 1984, just after an [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") game in which [Wayne Gretzky](/wiki/Wayne_Gretzky "Wayne Gretzky")'s [Edmonton Oilers](/wiki/Edmonton_Oilers "Edmonton Oilers") beat the [New Jersey Devils](/wiki/New_Jersey_Devils "New Jersey Devils") 13–4, Gretzky was quoted as saying to a reporter, "Well, it's time they got their act together, they're ruining the whole league. They had better stop running a _Mickey Mouse organization_ and put somebody on the ice". Reacting to Gretzky's comment, Devils fans wore Mickey Mouse apparel when the Oilers returned to New Jersey.[73]
  * In the 1993 Warner Bros. film _[Demolition Man](/wiki/Demolition_Man_\(film\) "Demolition Man \(film\)")_ , as [Sylvester Stallone](/wiki/Sylvester_Stallone "Sylvester Stallone")'s character is fighting the malfunctioning [AI](/wiki/AI "AI") of his out-of-control police car, he shouts for the system to "Brake! Brake! Brake now, you _Mickey Mouse piece of shit!_ "[74]
  * In the 1996 Warner Bros. film _[Space Jam](/wiki/Space_Jam "Space Jam")_ , [Bugs Bunny](/wiki/Bugs_Bunny "Bugs Bunny") derogatorily comments on [Daffy Duck](/wiki/Daffy_Duck "Daffy Duck")'s idea for the name of their basketball team, asking: "What kind of Mickey Mouse organization would name a team 'The Ducks?'" (This also referenced the [Mighty Ducks of Anaheim](/wiki/Anaheim_Ducks "Anaheim Ducks"), an [NHL](/wiki/National_Hockey_League "National Hockey League") team that was then owned by Disney, as well as the Disney-made ["The Mighty Ducks"](/wiki/The_Mighty_Ducks_\(film_series\) "The Mighty Ducks \(film series\)") movie franchise. This was referencing the Disney/Warner Brothers rivalry.)
  * In the United States armed forces, actions that look good but have little or no practical use (such as the specific manner of making beds in basic training or the polishing of brass fittings on board ship) are commonly referred to as "Mickey Mouse work."[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
  * In schools a "Mickey Mouse course", "Mickey Mouse major", or "[Mickey Mouse degree](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_degrees "Mickey Mouse degrees")" is a class, college major, or degree where very little effort is necessary in order to attain a good grade (especially an A) or one where the subject matter of such a class is not of any importance in the labor market.[75]
  * Musicians often refer to a film score that directly follows each action on screen as _[Mickey Mousing](/wiki/Mickey_Mousing "Mickey Mousing")_ (also _mickey-mousing_ and _mickeymousing_).[76]
  * Software company [Microsoft](/wiki/Microsoft "Microsoft") has been derogatorily called "Mickeysoft".[77]
  * In the beginning of the 1980s, then-British [Prime Minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister "Prime Minister") [Margaret Thatcher](/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher "Margaret Thatcher") once called the [European Parliament](/wiki/European_Parliament "European Parliament") a "Mickey Mouse parliament", meaning a discussion club without influence.[78]
  * In the British sitcom _[Red Dwarf](/wiki/Red_Dwarf "Red Dwarf")_ , in the episode ["Quarantine"](/wiki/Quarantine_\(Red_Dwarf\) "Quarantine \(Red Dwarf\)"), after the team's substandard equipment nearly cost them their lives, Lister pointed out, "We're a real Mickey Mouse operation, aren't we?" The Cat replied, "Mickey Mouse? We ain't even [Betty Boop](/wiki/Betty_Boop "Betty Boop")!"
  * The [combined road course](/wiki/Oval_track_racing#Combined_road_course "Oval track racing") at the [Indianapolis Motor Speedway](/wiki/Indianapolis_Motor_Speedway "Indianapolis Motor Speedway") used for the [F1](/wiki/Formula_One "Formula One") [U.S. Grand Prix](/wiki/United_States_Grand_Prix "United States Grand Prix") has been described by [Jacques Villeneuve](/wiki/Jacques_Villeneuve "Jacques Villeneuve") and other competitors as "Mickey Mouse"[79] due to its slow uninteresting corners, and lack of challenging corners.

### Parodies and criticism

Mickey Mouse's global fame has made him both a symbol of [The Walt Disney
Company](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company") and of the
United States itself. For this reason, Mickey has been used frequently in
[anti-American](/wiki/Anti-American "Anti-American") [satire](/wiki/Satire
"Satire"), such as the infamous underground cartoon "_[Mickey Mouse in
Vietnam](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_in_Vietnam "Mickey Mouse in Vietnam")_ " (1969).
There have been numerous [parodies](/wiki/Parody "Parody") of Mickey Mouse,
such as the 2-page parody _" Mickey Rodent"_ by [Will Elder](/wiki/Will_Elder
"Will Elder") (published in _[Mad](/wiki/Mad_\(magazine\) "Mad \(magazine\)")_
#19, 1955) in which the mouse walks around unshaven and jails [Donald
Duck](/wiki/Donald_Duck "Donald Duck") out of jealousy over the duck's larger
popularity.[80] The grotesque [Rat Fink](/wiki/Rat_Fink "Rat Fink") character
was created by [Ed "Big Daddy" Roth](/wiki/Ed_%22Big_Daddy%22_Roth "Ed "Big
Daddy" Roth") over his hatred of Mickey Mouse. In _[The Simpsons
Movie](/wiki/The_Simpsons_Movie "The Simpsons Movie")_ , [Bart
Simpson](/wiki/Bart_Simpson "Bart Simpson") puts a black bra on his head to
mimic Mickey Mouse and says: "I'm the mascot of an [evil
corporation](/wiki/Evil_corporation "Evil corporation")!"[81] On the [Comedy
Central](/wiki/Comedy_Central "Comedy Central") series _[South
Park](/wiki/South_Park "South Park")_ , Mickey is depicted as the sadistic,
greedy, foul-mouthed boss of [The Walt Disney
Company](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company"), only
interested in money. He also appears briefly with [Donald
Duck](/wiki/Donald_Duck "Donald Duck") in the comic _[Squeak the
Mouse](/wiki/Squeak_the_Mouse "Squeak the Mouse")_ by the Italian cartoonist
[Massimo Mattioli](/wiki/Massimo_Mattioli "Massimo Mattioli").

In the 1969 parody novel _[Bored of the Rings](/wiki/Bored_of_the_Rings "Bored
of the Rings")_ , Mickey Mouse is satirized as Dickey Dragon.

## Legal issues

Like all major Disney characters, Mickey Mouse is not only
[copyrighted](/wiki/Copyright "Copyright") but also
[trademarked](/wiki/Trademark "Trademark"), which lasts in perpetuity as long
as it continues to be used commercially by its owner. So, whether or not a
particular Disney cartoon goes into the [public domain](/wiki/Public_domain
"Public domain"), the characters themselves may not be used as trademarks
without authorization.

Because of the [Copyright Term Extension
Act](/wiki/Copyright_Term_Extension_Act "Copyright Term Extension Act") of the
United States (sometimes called the 'Mickey Mouse Protection Act' because of
extensive lobbying by the Disney corporation) and similar legislation within
the [European Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union") and other
jurisdictions where [copyright terms](/wiki/Copyright_term "Copyright term")
have been extended, works such as the early Mickey Mouse cartoons will remain
under copyright until at least 2023. However, some copyright scholars argue
that Disney's copyright on the earliest version of the character may be
invalid due to ambiguity in the copyright notice for _[Steamboat
Willie](/wiki/Steamboat_Willie "Steamboat Willie")_.[82]

The Walt Disney Company has become well known for protecting its trademark on
the Mickey Mouse character—whose likeness is closely associated with the
company—with particular zeal. In 1989, Disney threatened legal action against
three daycare centers in [Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida") for having Mickey
Mouse and other Disney characters painted on their walls. The characters were
removed, and rival [Universal Studios](/wiki/Universal_Studios "Universal
Studios") replaced them with Universal cartoon characters.[83]

### _Walt Disney Productions v. Air Pirates_

In 1971, a group of [underground cartoonists](/wiki/Underground_comix
"Underground comix") calling themselves the [Air Pirates](/wiki/Air_Pirates
"Air Pirates"), after a group of villains from early Mickey Mouse films,
produced a comic called _Air Pirates Funnies_. In the first issue, cartoonist
[Dan O'Neill](/wiki/Dan_O%27Neill "Dan O'Neill") depicted Mickey and Minnie
Mouse engaging in explicit sexual behavior and consuming drugs. As O'Neill
explained, "The air pirates were…some sort of bizarre concept to steal the
air, pirate the air, steal the media….Since we were cartoonists, the logical
thing was Disney."[84] Rather than change the appearance or name of the
character, which O'Neill felt would dilute the parody, the mouse depicted in
_Air Pirates Funnies_ looks like and is named "Mickey Mouse". Disney sued for
copyright infringement, and after a series of appeals, O'Neill eventually lost
and was ordered to pay Disney $1.9 million. The outcome of the case remains
controversial among free-speech advocates. New York Law School professor
Edward Samuels said, "[The Air Pirates] set parody back twenty
years."[85][_[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")_]

### Censorship

In 1930, The [German](/wiki/Germany "Germany") Board of Film Censors
prohibited any presentations of the Mickey Mouse cartoon _[The Barnyard
Battle](/wiki/The_Barnyard_Battle "The Barnyard Battle")_ (1929). The animated
short, which features the mouse as a [kepi](/wiki/Kepi "Kepi")-wearing soldier
fighting cat enemies in German-style helmets, was viewed by censors as a
negative portrayal of Germany.[86] It was claimed by the board that the film
would "reawaken the latest anti-German feeling existing abroad since the
War".[87] The _Barnyard Battle_ incident did not incite wider anti-Mickey
sentiment in Germany in 1930; however, after [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler
"Adolf Hitler") came to power several years later, the Nazi regime
unambiguously propagandized against Disney. A mid-1930s German newspaper
article read:

> "Mickey Mouse is the most miserable ideal ever revealed...Healthy emotions
> tell every independent young man and every honorable youth that the dirty
> and filth-covered vermin, the greatest bacteria carrier in the animal
> kingdom, cannot be the ideal type of animal...Away with Jewish brutalization
> of the people! Down with Mickey Mouse! Wear the [Swastika
> Cross](/wiki/Nazi_swastika "Nazi swastika")!"[88][89][90]

American cartoonist and writer [Art Spiegelman](/wiki/Art_Spiegelman "Art
Spiegelman") would later use this quote on the opening page of the second
volume of his graphic novel _[Maus](/wiki/Maus "Maus")_.

In 1935 Romanian authorities also [banned](/wiki/Ban_\(legal\) "Ban
\(legal\)") Mickey Mouse films from [cinemas](/wiki/Movie_theater "Movie
theater"), purportedly fearing that children would be "scared to see a ten-
foot mouse in the movie theatre".[91] In 1938, based on the [Ministry of
Popular Culture](/wiki/Ministry_of_Popular_Culture "Ministry of Popular
Culture")'s recommendation that a reform was necessary "to raise children in
the firm and imperialist spirit of the Fascist revolution," the [Italian
Government](/wiki/Italian_Government "Italian Government") banned foreign
[children's literature](/wiki/Children%27s_literature "Children's
literature")[92] except Mickey; Disney characters were exempted from the
decree for the "acknowledged artistic merit" of Disney's work.[93] Actually,
Mussolini's children were fond of Mickey Mouse, so they managed to delay his
ban as long as possible.[94] In 1942, after Italy declared war on the United
States, fascism immediately forced Italian publishers to stop printing any
Disney stories. Mickey's stories were replaced by the adventures of
_Tuffolino_ , a new human character created by Federico Pedrocchi (script) and
Pier Lorenzo De Vita (art). After the downfall of Italy's fascist government
in 1945, the ban was removed.

## Filmography

Main article: [List of Mickey Mouse films and
appearances](/wiki/List_of_Mickey_Mouse_films_and_appearances "List of Mickey
Mouse films and appearances")

Mickey has been announced to star in two films. One is a live-action/CGI
hybrid film based on the Magic Kingdom theme park at the Walt Disney World
Resort,[95] while the other is a film idea pitched by Walt Disney Animation
Studios veteran Burny Mattinson centering on Mickey, Donald, and Goofy.[38]
